utterances: Yeah.

...but it's important.
Yeah, the arts are hurting.

She's a visual artist.
For three years now, those seem to be the programs that seem to be gone the fastest.
And Michigan - well, not just the federal government, the state government there is in dire straits, as well.

No. They don't.

And Catherine Rampell, yeah, the arts are an important sector.
We forget that sometimes.
Well, and they're suffering, not only because government money has been drying up, you know.
They're - these governments are having trouble paying their more - what they would consider - essential bills, you know, keeping the lights on in their offices or whatever.
And they're less likely to be spending money for the arts, whether in schools or elsewhere.
And beyond that, you have nonprofits that also end up giving a lot of grant money for performing arts, visual arts, and they've been hurting, too, because their donations are drying up.
Catherine Rampell, thanks very much for your time.
Thank you.
And we thank everybody who called and wrote to us on this subject.
It's one to which we will return as the situation continues to develop.

This is NPR News.
It's your time to shine.
That means letters.
Joining me is NEWS & NOTES producer Christopher Johnson.
Hey, Christopher.
Hey, Farai.
Welcome back from Zimbabwe.
Well, thanks.
It was great to see my family.
I'll tell you more about that later, but what have we got?
Well, there's some outrage about how we handled Barack Obama.
Michael Taglieri(ph) of New York City wrote this after our segment on Monday on Obama's official bid for the White House.
Obama has problems with support from African-Americans because Obama is not really an African-American.
People like Obama who came to the United States after the Civil Rights Movement have no real connection to the history of slavery or what African-Americans went through to get where they are now.
Tamara Jones(ph) had a different beef about the segment.
She said it would helpful to compare questions directed towards Obama with those going to other Democrats.
For example, what is the keystone of Hillary's campaign?
What is the biggest challenge she faces?
And Kathleen Lions Candeleria(ph) of Billings, Montana wrote in with this suggestion.
Please try note to follow the journalistic pack and focus only on Clinton and Obama or McCain and Giuliani.
There are many very talented candidates.
Give airtime to all candidates to give balanced coverage.
Last week, Roundtable commentator Joe Davidson had his say about Guinea Bissau.
The West African nation is encouraging Whoopi Goldberg to renew ties there after DNA tests show it could be her homeland.
Buchman says Ford stressed to her students the importance of reading empirical research with a critical eye.

I think that a few have to kind of grab on to an American entertainer in order to draw attention to your small West African country, it shows just how far off the radar screen you are from most Americans.
Now, Joe got Wally Adu-Woomi(ph)of Newark, New Jersey going.
He wrote I am greatly offended by Joe's remarks.
Africa will continue to exist without crawling to Whoopi Goldberg.
Well, I have to say, as someone who's just back from Southern Africa, there are a mix of good and bad stories occurring on the continent.
And one of the things that we do here at NEWS & NOTES is check in with Charlayne Hunter-Gault.
She's our NPR's special Africa correspondent.
So we'll continue to bring you the things that are going positively on the continent, as well as the things that need to be changed.
Christopher?
Well, finally, Farai, Joyce Oliver was one of several who wrote us about our recent interview with R&B singer-songwriter Bill Withers.
Joyce said, thank you so much for his segment.
I've always wondered why he stopped recording.
I'm sure he's written more songs.
What is he going to do with them?
Well, we went back to our original recording with Mr. Withers.
He didn't tell us how many songs he had in the can, but he did say this in an outtake dug up by my colleague, Roy Hurst.
Now I probably have something rattling around in my head that's very personal.
But if you're asking me if I am sitting around all the time going, man, I got to do something else so I can go show off again.
No.
And speaking of personal songs, Farai, as far as I'm concerned, Bill never has to write another one after he pinned this gem in '74.
It's my favorite of his, called ""Make a Smile for Me.
(Soundbite of song, ""Make a Smile for Me"")
(Singing) Lately, I've been so lonely and a smile from you might make these blues go away.
Well, Christopher, I have to say that ""Use Me"" is my favorite tune.
And I was at this award ceremony where he got a lifetime award.
And he said people always ask me what my songs mean, but really they mean just what they say.
So when I say ""Use Me,"" I was thinking use me.
When I said ""Lean on Me,"" I was thinking lean on me.
So he's one funny man in addition to being a very talented songwriter.
Right on.
